content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a lot of trouble sleeping lately. It's gotten to the point where I have all these racing thoughts about work and financial stress, and I just can't seem to turn my brain off at night. My partner pushed me to see someone about it, so I figured I'd give this a try.

Thank you for sharing that—it sounds like you're carrying a lot of stress right now. Trouble sleeping can feel overwhelming, especially when it’s tied to those racing thoughts about work and finances. It also sounds like your partner cares about you and wants you to get support, which is a good step forward. What do you feel has been the biggest challenge for you during this time?

I think the biggest challenge is that I can't seem to turn my mind off. I'm constantly thinking about work, how I might get fired, and how I'm going to pay the bills if that happens. It feels like this cycle that I can't break, and then I make it worse by scrolling on my phone, even though I know it's not helping. I just feel stuck.

It sounds like you’re caught in a tough cycle where the stress about work and finances keeps escalating, making it hard to find some calm or relief. And even though scrolling on your phone might not be helping, it’s understandable that you’re trying to distract yourself in some way—it shows you're doing your best to cope under pressure. Feeling stuck can take a toll. What do you think would help you feel less stuck or more in control?

Honestly, I’m not sure what would help. I feel like even if I tried something, I’d still be stuck worrying about work. Maybe if I could figure out how to stop these racing thoughts or actually believe things might get better, but I don’t know how to do that right now.

You're expressing a lot of self-awareness about what you're facing, which is an important first step. It sounds like you’ve been reflecting on ways to quiet your mind and regain a sense of hope, even though it feels distant right now. Staying in this space of worry can make it hard to see solutions, but you've already taken a thoughtful step by talking about it. What would things look like for you if those racing thoughts started to ease up?

If the racing thoughts eased up, I feel like I’d finally have a chance to actually rest and maybe feel a bit more relaxed, at least at night. I’d feel more present with my family and just less overwhelmed in general. But right now, that feels so far away—like I don’t even know how to take the first step to get there.

It sounds like you have a clear picture of where you want to be—rested, relaxed, more present with your family, and less overwhelmed—and that vision matters. Even though it feels far away right now, it's meaningful that you're thinking about what could change. Feeling unsure about the first step is okay; many people feel that way when they're facing something difficult. What do you think has kept you from taking steps toward that vision before now?

I think it’s mostly that I feel stuck in this loop. Work stress feels so big and immediate, and by the time I get to the end of the day, I’m so drained that it’s hard to even think about trying something new. Plus, I feel like no matter what I do, the stress is still going to be there, so it’s hard to believe things could actually change.

It sounds like the constant stress and exhaustion have made it hard to see how things could improve, and it’s tough to feel motivated when the stress feels like it will always be there. At the same time, it seems like part of you is wondering what steps you could take and whether change might be possible, even if you don’t fully believe it right now. What’s kept you going, even as you're navigating all of this?

I think what keeps me going is my family. I want to provide for them and be someone my kids can look up to. Even though it’s hard, I don’t want to let them down, and that pushes me to keep trying, even when I feel overwhelmed.

Your dedication to your family is really powerful—it shows how deeply you care and how much they mean to you. Wanting to be someone your kids can look up to is a strong motivator, even when things feel overwhelming. That determination you have might be an important part of finding the changes you’re looking for. What would it mean to you—and to them—to feel more rested and present with your family?

I think it would mean everything, honestly. I’d feel like I’m finally giving them the version of me they deserve—someone who’s patient, engaged, and able to enjoy being with them rather than being distracted or snappy all the time. I just want them to see that even through all the stress, I still care and want to be there for them completely.

That’s such a meaningful aspiration—to show your family how much you care by being present, patient, and engaged. It’s clear how much love and effort you’re already putting into being there for them, even in tough moments, and wanting to move closer to the version of yourself you imagine they deserve speaks volumes about your commitment. What do you think could be a small step toward building that kind of presence?

Maybe something small, like putting my phone away earlier in the evening or trying to set aside a little time just for my kids, even if I’m stressed. I’m not sure if it would fix everything, but it might help me feel more connected to them for a moment, and maybe that would make the stress feel a little less heavy.

That sounds like a thoughtful idea—small shifts like putting your phone away or dedicating even a little time to your kids can create moments of connection, which might lighten the weight of your stress, even briefly. It’s encouraging that you’re exploring steps that feel manageable, especially given everything you’re juggling. How do you feel about starting with one of those steps?

You know what? I think I could try putting my phone away earlier. It might help me wind down a bit, and it would also show my kids that I’m giving them my full attention for a while. It’s not a big step, but maybe it’s a good place to start.

That sounds like a great place to start—it's a small, manageable step that could make a big difference in how you feel at night and how connected you are with your kids. It’s thoughtful and achievable, and trying it out is a sign of your commitment to your family and yourself. Is there anything else you’d like to talk through before we wrap up or begin planning more steps?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation for now. Thank you for speaking about this with me—it’s helped me think a bit more clearly about where to start.
